sections.title: The Zeal of Matathias and the Beginning of Revolt
The Death of Mattathias and His Final Blessing

verses.text: In those days Matathias, the son of John, the son of Simeon, a priest from the descendants of Joarib, moved from Jerusalem and settled in Modein.
verses.comment: Matathias is established here as a priest of the Joarib family, grounding the narrative firmly in the lineage of temple service. This is significant, as priestly authority becomes central to the events that follow.

verses.text: He had five sons: John, called Gaddi;
verses.comment: Listing the sons introduces the principal characters of the resistance, emphasizing the importance of family and the transmission of faith through generations.

verses.text: Simon, called Thassi;
verses.comment: Simon will play an important leadership role later in the Maccabean revolt.

verses.text: Judas, who was called Maccabeus;
verses.comment: Judas, later known as Maccabeus, becomes the primary leader—his nickname means 'the Hammer.'

verses.text: Eleazar, called Avaran, and Jonathan, called Apphus.
verses.comment: All five sons are mentioned, each with a unique role in Israel’s struggle for fidelity to God's law.

verses.text: He saw the blasphemies being committed in Judah and Jerusalem,
verses.comment: Matathias’s grief stems from witnessing the desecration of the temple and violation of the covenant.

verses.text: and he said, 'Alas! Why was I born to see the ruin of my people and the ruin of the holy city, and to live there when it was given over to the enemy, and the sanctuary to foreigners?
verses.comment: Matathias's lament echoes prophets and psalmists mourning the destruction of Jerusalem and the temple—a foreshadowing of Christ’s own lament over Jerusalem (Luke 19:41-44).

verses.text: Her temple has become like a man dishonored;
verses.comment: The defilement of the temple is compared to the shame of a person, showing the depth of spiritual tragedy.

verses.text: her glorious vessels have been carried off as booty, her infants slaughtered in her streets, her young men fallen by the sword of the enemy.
verses.comment: The suffering of the people is connected intimately to the desecration of the temple. The fate of the people and worship are intertwined.

verses.text: What nation has not claimed her as a prize and taken possession of her spoils?
verses.comment: A rhetorical question emphasizing Israel’s humiliation among the nations, relating to prophecies of judgment (Deuteronomy 28:49-57).

verses.text: All her adornment has been taken away. Instead of being free, she has become a slave.
verses.comment: Israel's loss of freedom symbolizes a loss of her special covenant relationship.

verses.text: And behold, our holy place, our beauty, and our glory have been laid waste, and the Gentiles have profaned them.
verses.comment: A summary of the ways in which pagan nations have defiled the sanctuary, emphasizing the severity of the crisis.

verses.text: Why should we go on living any longer?
verses.comment: This reveals how deeply the people felt the loss of their liturgical life—something restored in an even greater way through Christ’s ultimate sacrifice.

verses.text: And Matathias and his sons tore their clothes, put on sackcloth, and mourned greatly.
verses.comment: The traditional mourning actions underscore their priestly connection and faithfulness to the covenant, anticipating themes of priestly suffering fulfilled in the High Priest Jesus (Hebrews 4:14-16).

verses.text: Then the king's officers who were compelling the people to abandon the law came to the town of Modein to enforce the sacrifice.
verses.comment: The arrival of the king’s agents brings the apostasy to Matathias’s doorstep, setting up the act of faithful resistance.

verses.text: Many Israelites came over to them, but Matathias and his sons stood firm together.
verses.comment: Contrast is drawn between those who conform and those who remain faithful, echoing the remnant motif developed throughout Scripture (see Isaiah 10:20-22).

verses.text: Then the king's officers addressed Matathias: 'You are a leader, highly honored and great in this city, and supported by sons and brothers.
verses.comment: Pressure is placed on those with influence, paralleling the temptation to betray faith for power.

verses.text: 'Come forward now, be the first to obey the king’s command, as all the Gentiles, the people of Judah, and those left in Jerusalem have done. Then you and your sons will be counted among the Friends of the king, and you and your sons will be honored with silver and gold and many gifts.'
verses.comment: Temptation to betray God in exchange for worldly honor recalls Christ’s temptation in the desert (Matthew 4:8-10), and the lure of earthly reward over fidelity to God.

verses.text: But Matathias answered in a loud voice: 'Even if all the nations that live under the king's rule obey him and forsake the religion of their ancestors, choosing to obey his orders,
verses.comment: Matathias’s public refusal models courageous confession of the faith, an important virtue throughout the history of the Church.

verses.text: yet I, my sons, and my brothers will continue to live by the covenant of our ancestors.
verses.comment: Standing firm in the covenant reflects steadfast faithfulness, which is at the core of Christian continuity from Old to New Covenant.

verses.text: God forbid that we should abandon the law and the commandments.
verses.comment: Refusing to turn from the law, Matathias upholds the principle of divine authority, anticipating Christ's words about the law’s fulfillment (Matthew 5:17-19).

verses.text: We will not obey the king's words by turning aside from our religion to the right hand or to the left.'
verses.comment: Fidelity is expressed as a refusal to compromise even in small ways—core for understanding true perseverance in faith.

verses.text: When he had finished speaking, a Jew came forward in the sight of all to offer sacrifice on the altar in Modein, according to the king’s command.
verses.comment: This public act of apostasy sparks the pivotal moment in the narrative—the clear division between those who conform and those who remain steadfast.

verses.text: When Matathias saw it, he was filled with zeal, and his heart trembled. He gave vent to righteous anger, ran up and killed him on the altar.
verses.comment: Matathias’s zealous act recalls that of Phinehas (Numbers 25:11), highlighting the serious defense of the faith and foreshadowing Christ’s righteous anger in the temple (John 2:13-17).

verses.text: At the same time, he killed the king's officer who was forcing them to sacrifice, and he tore down the altar.
verses.comment: The destruction of the altar constructed for false worship shows the exclusive devotion demanded by the one true God.

verses.text: Thus he burned with zeal for the law, as Phinehas did against Zimri the son of Salu.
verses.comment: Direct comparison to Phinehas strengthens the theme of priestly zeal, which prefigures the priestly zeal fulfilled perfectly in Christ.

verses.text: Then Matathias cried out with a loud voice in the city, saying, 'Let everyone who is zealous for the law and supports the covenant come out and follow me!'
verses.comment: A call to faithful remnant, invoking Moses’ own rallying cry (Exodus 32:26). This prefigures the call to discipleship in the New Testament, which demands total self-giving (cf. Luke 9:23).
verses.sectionHeader: The Zeal of Matathias and the Beginning of Revolt

verses.text: So he and his sons fled into the mountains and left behind all that they owned in the city.
verses.comment: Abandoning earthly possessions for the sake of faith resembles Christ’s call to the rich young man (Matthew 19:21), and the call to leave all for the kingdom.

verses.text: Then many who sought righteousness and justice went down into the wilderness to live there,
verses.comment: Wilderness retreat for faithfulness is a theme from Israel’s history, echoing the Exodus and later, John the Baptist’s ministry.

verses.text: they, their children, their wives, and their livestock, because troubles pressed so hard on them.
verses.comment: The entire community—families included—sought refuge, emphasizing that the faith is transmitted and protected communally, not just individually.

verses.text: And it was reported to the king’s officers and the troops stationed in Jerusalem, in the city of David, that men who had rejected the king's order had gone down to hiding places in the wilderness.
verses.comment: This verse hints at a tradition of holy resistance, as seen with David and earlier prophets.

verses.text: Many pursued them, and overtook them; they encamped opposite them and prepared to attack them on the sabbath day.
verses.comment: Their enemies take advantage of their Sabbath observance, showing the cost of faithfulness.

verses.text: They said to them, 'Come out and obey the king’s command, and you will live.'
verses.comment: The enemy presents a false choice between life and faithfulness, similar to the choices offered to early Christian martyrs.

verses.text: But they replied, 'We will not come out, nor will we do the king’s command and profane the sabbath day.'
verses.comment: Choosing obedience to God’s law over life itself testifies to the sanctity of the Sabbath and prefigures Christian martyrs’ commitment to truth even unto death.

verses.text: So the enemy rushed upon them immediately.
verses.comment: Choosing faithfulness often brings immediate persecution.

verses.text: But they did not lift a stone or block up the hiding places,
verses.comment: Rigid observance of the Sabbath—even in the face of death—highlights the sincerity of their piety and how they interpret the law prior to Christ’s fulfillment.

verses.text: for they said, 'Let us all die in our innocence. Heaven and earth testify for us that you are killing us unjustly.'
verses.comment: Their trust in God's vindication echoes the suffering servant (Isaiah 53) and anticipates Christian instruction on redemptive suffering.

verses.text: So they attacked them on the sabbath, and they died, with their wives and children and livestock, to the number of a thousand people.
verses.comment: Martyrdom here foreshadows Christian martyrs who would ‘not love their lives even to death’ (Revelation 12:11); communal suffering and faithfulness are highlighted.

verses.text: When Matathias and his friends learned about it, they mourned deeply for them.
verses.comment: Grief at the loss of the martyrs reflects the Church’s veneration of those who give their lives for fidelity to God.

verses.text: And they said to one another, 'If we all do as our brothers have done, and refuse to fight against the pagans for our lives and our religion, they will quickly destroy us from the earth.'
verses.comment: A pivotal shift occurs here: faithfulness will now include defending religion by force if needed. Later Christian reflection would recognize here a development in understanding the relation of law to love, discipline, and community defense.

verses.text: So they came to an agreement that on whatever day anyone was attacked by the enemy for Sabbath, they would fight back rather than be destroyed—so they would not all die as their brothers did in the caves.
verses.comment: This verse reflects the early Jewish struggle to interpret the Sabbath law in the face of mortal danger. Jesus later comments on the true meaning of Sabbath, prioritizing mercy and life over ritual (Mark 2:23-28).

verses.text: Then a group of devout Jews, called Hasideans, joined themselves to Mattathias and his sons, strong supporters of Israel.
verses.comment: The Hasideans were early promoters of faithfulness to the Law, a foreshadow of spiritual communities dedicated to holiness and tradition, such as those among ancient Israel.

verses.text: Everyone fleeing persecution joined them, and they became a firm support for Israel.
verses.comment: The solidarity among the persecuted echoes later Christian teaching on unity in suffering (Hebrews 10:32-39).

verses.text: They formed an army and struck down sinners in their fury and evil-doers in their wrath. The rest fled to safety.
verses.comment: Taking up the sword against evil can be seen as a last resort to safeguard spiritual purity (Psalm 149:6-9).

verses.text: Mattathias and his friends went all around, pulling down pagan altars.
verses.comment: Destroying pagan altars mirrors the Deuteronomic commands to purge idolatry, affirming the exclusivity of proper worship.

verses.text: They forcibly circumcised all the uncircumcised boys they found in Israel.
verses.comment: Circumcision was a mark of covenant fidelity (Genesis 17:9-14), later seen spiritually fulfilled through faith (Romans 2:25-29).

verses.text: They succeeded in their campaign, pursuing arrogant men.
verses.comment: Pride leads to destruction—a recurring theme in both Old and New Testaments (Proverbs 16:18-19).

verses.text: They restored the Law from the hands of the Gentiles and from kings, and did not let the horn of sin prevail.
verses.comment: Restoring the Law points towards God's fidelity in preserving His covenant people and their worship.

verses.text: When the days of Mattathias drew to an end, he said to his sons, "Now arrogance and scorn have grown strong; it is a time of devastation and furious anger.
verses.comment: Mattathias’ dying words invoke the reality of evil, a prompt to trust in providence and endurance.

verses.text: So, my children, be zealous for the Law, and give your lives for the covenant of our ancestors.
verses.comment: The call to self-sacrifice aligns with the teaching of Christ on taking up one's cross (Matthew 10:38-39), showing the deep tradition of giving all for faith.

verses.text: Remember the deeds of our ancestors, accomplished each in their generation; you will receive great honor and an everlasting name.
verses.comment: The notion of an everlasting name hints at resurrection hope (Hebrews 11:32-40) and spiritual legacy.

verses.text: Was not Abraham found faithful when tested, and it was credited to him as righteousness?
verses.comment: A reference to Abraham's obedience links faith with works, foundational to understanding faithfulness.

verses.text: Joseph in his time kept the commandment, and became lord of Egypt.
verses.comment: Joseph's rise exemplifies divine providence rewarding faithfulness in adversity.

verses.text: Phinehas our father, because he had great zeal, received the covenant of eternal priesthood.
verses.comment: Phinehas’ zeal is commended with the gift of priesthood—an enduring office deeply connected to worship.

verses.text: Joshua, when he fulfilled his role, was made judge in Israel.
verses.comment: Joshua’s leadership highlights the importance of apostolic succession in guiding God's people through new eras.

verses.text: Caleb, for giving witness before the assembly, received an inheritance in the land.
verses.comment: Caleb’s bold profession underscores the reward for true witnesses in faith.

verses.text: David, for his loyalty, inherited the throne of the eternal kingdom.
verses.comment: David's kingdom is described as eternal, an allusion to the messianic hope fulfilled in Christ (Luke 1:32-33).

verses.text: Elijah, for his burning zeal for the Law, was taken up to heaven.
verses.comment: Elijah’s righteous passion leads to his heavenly translation—a sign of hope in bodily resurrection.

verses.text: Hananiah, Azariah, and Mishael were saved from the flame because of their faith.
verses.comment: Salvation from judgment by fire prefigures divine deliverance and victory over suffering (Daniel 3:19-29).

verses.text: Daniel was rescued from the lions because of his innocence.
verses.comment: Daniel’s protection echoes the theme of God preserving those steadfast in spirit.

verses.text: Consider this from generation to generation: All who hope in him will never be forsaken.
verses.comment: God's promise to never abandon the faithful is a core teaching realized in Christ’s assurance (Matthew 28:20).

verses.text: Do not be afraid of sinful men, but remember what they did to our ancestors, and you will not fear.
verses.comment: The call to holy courage stems from trust in God more than fear of men.

verses.text: Keep in mind that punishment is for the wicked, while glory awaits the righteous.
verses.comment: The justice of reward and punishment points toward the resurrection and eternal life (Daniel 12:1-3, Matthew 25:46).

verses.text: So, my sons, act with courage and stand strong in the Law, because the Law will bring you glory.
verses.comment: Courage and obedience to the Law prepare the faithful for glory—both temporal and eternal.

verses.text: Here is your brother Simon, who I know is wise in counsel; always listen to him—he will be a father to you.
verses.comment: Mattathias designates Simon as leader, highlighting spiritual fatherhood as a key aspect of continuity and wisdom.

verses.text: Judas, called Maccabeus, has shown strength from his youth; he shall be your commander, and lead you in battle.
verses.comment: Appointing Judas as military leader parallels the biblical precedent for God raising up deliverers for His people.

verses.text: Bring together all who observe the Law, and avenge the wrong done to your people.
verses.comment: Unity among the faithful and righteous justice are emphasized as the means to restoration.

verses.text: Pay back the Gentiles in full, and obey what the Law commands.
verses.comment: Justice is given urgency but is tempered by obedience, reflecting the biblical balance of retribution and submission to God's law.

verses.text: He blessed them and was gathered to his ancestors.
verses.comment: The blessing and death of Mattathias recalls the patriarchal tradition of bestowing spiritual inheritance before passing.

verses.text: Mattathias died in the one hundred and forty-sixth year and was buried in his ancestors’ tomb at Modein. All Israel mourned deeply for him.
verses.comment: The mourning for Mattathias evokes the theme of Israel's reverence for their heroes whose faith points beyond death to hope of resurrection.
verses.sectionHeader: The Death of Mattathias and His Final Blessing
